svg.content: <mxfile host="Electron" modified="2023-11-12T11:03:35.362Z" agent="Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) draw.io/22.0.3 Chrome/114.0.5735.289 Electron/25.8.4 Safari/537.36" etag="5upsvcrGmwJxZxb7EgE6" version="22.0.3" type="device"><diagram name="Pagina-1" id="L0RKP73ELEkKzpf2K_hG"></diagram></mxfile>

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 158px; height: 1px; padding-top: 21px; margin-left: 111px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

div.div:
Binary Sistem
(Binary = formed by 0 and 1)
Byte (B) = formed by 8 bits

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 178px; height: 1px; padding-top: 136px; margin-left: 101px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;
div.font:
How to get a binary number
1) Factorize the number (divide the number always per 2 - recursively)
2) Do the code on the right
3) Write the number

switch.text: How to get a binary number...

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 138px; height: 1px; padding-top: 141px; margin-left: 341px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;
display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 228px; height: 1px; padding-top: 236px; margin-left: 511px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;
div.font:
ASCII
2^8 = 256 characters
Each character you type it's encoded via a bit
(link:ASCII-Table.png (1968×1292) (ohio-state.edu)

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 358px; height: 1px; padding-top: 426px; margin-left: 1px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;
div.font:
Analogue vs Digital technology
Analogue = Signals of variable eletric pulses
Digital = Translated and encoded into bits
- Analog are continuous signals, use more energy
- Digital are discrete signals and use energy in a reduced way, are more efficient and can overcome obstacles
You need analogue to digital converter = audio/photo to bits and then to digital signals
You need digital to analogue converter = to understand computer output

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 358px; height: 1px; padding-top: 426px; margin-left: 391px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;
div.font:
Evolution of computers (history)
Some examples of calculators iovertime able to compute formulas and numbers via mechanical systems, punch cards, etc.
First (1) Generation: vacuum tube (ENIAC/UNIVAC)
Second (2) Generation: transistors and assembly
Third (3) Generation: Integrated circuits
Fourth (4) Generation: Single-chip computers
Fifth (5) Generation: parallel processing/AI/nanotecynology

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 418px; height: 1px; padding-top: 666px; margin-left: 171px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;
div.font:
Present and future of computers
Current generation revolves on ULSI (Ultra Large-Scale Integration) = billions of circuits on a single chips allowing faster processing
Sixth (6) Generation: AI computers solving problems efficiently
Future generations:
- neurons rather than physical (intelligent as human beings)
- connected with other devices at the same time (IoT - Internet of Things)
- operations over RNA/DNA (biological operations)
- different ways of communication (voice/image recognition, emotion sensing, etc.)
- brain/computer interface (BCI), acquirijng brain signals and analyzing them

a.text: Text is not SVG - cannot display
